ml:doc-envelope.ml:original-txt:
Rwanda: Competitivenessand EnterpriseDevelopmentProject Release of SecondTranche -FullCompliance Cr. 3499-RW)
I. Background
1. The objective o fthe Project i s to establish an enablingenvironment for private sector-led economic growth and poverty reduction within the Borrower's territory
2. The project focuses on promoting a competitive climate by (i) streamliningthe business environment; (ii) reducing costs and increasing the efficiency o f telecommunications, water and electricity utilities, and the tea industry; and (iii) improving access to financial and support services to local entrepreneurs.
3. The project, built on the achievement o fthe closedRwanda Private Sector DevelopmentProject (Cr.245 1-RW),i s designed as a response o f the Bank Group to the request o f the client for creating abetter climate for private sector development in Rwanda. The project is a packaged response aimed at stimulating the demand side by enhancing investment promotionwith FIAS and MIGA andhelpingestablish conditions with the SME Group to provide financial and non- financial services to emerging or existing SMEs. Further, to respondto this demand, IDA i s working on reducing immediate threats to the financial sector and capacity improvement, while IFC will addressthe issue o f long-termresources and capital adequacy when conditions permit. IDAis also helpingto improve the legal environment and stimulate efficiency inutilities and tea sectors by loweringcosts through privatization.
11. RecentEconomicDevelopments
4. Between August and October 2003, an elected government, chosen through presidential and parliamentary elections, replaced the transitional govemment established immediately after the 1994 genocide. The new government reiterated its commitment to national reconciliation, economic reforms, and poverty reduction. Donors continue to provide generous financial and technical assistance.
5. In2002, performance under the first annual (Poverty ReductionGrowth Facility) PRGF review was satisfactory. For the period 2000-02, the growth rate averaged 7.4 percent with low and stable inflation, making Rwanda one o f the best performers in Sub- Saharan Africa. Revenue performance reached a level o f 13.4% in 2003, up from, 12.2 percent o f GDP in 2002, 11.4% in 2001, (and 9.7 percent in 2000). Social spending increased gradually to 6.3% o f GDP in 2003 (compared to 6.1 percent in 2002, 5.3 percent in 2001, and 4 percent in 2000). In addition, to enhance public sector productivity, the Government embarked on reforms in public expenditure and financial management, and related public institutions. In 2003, external shocks to production and prices hampered economic growth. GDP growth was estimated to be below 3%, with inflation at 7.7%, compared to 9.4 percent GDP growth and 2 percent inflation in 2002. The reductioninthe level o f growth was mainly due to drought conditions duringthe late  2002 and early 2003 period. While agriculture production dropped slightly, construction grew by about 15 percent (construction accounts for about 10percent o fthe economy).
6. In addition to the drought conditions and poor economic growth, in 2003, there were also unforeseen expenditures which exacerbated the fiscal situation. For the first time since the genocide, Rwanda held presidential and parliamentary elections. These elections, which are important for establishing a more stable political framework, cost more money than expected or programmed in the budget. An attempt to raise funds from the population resulted intotal donations o f $2 million, which was not sufficient to cover the cost o f the elections. In addition, programmed donor grants, which were expected to be disbursed inearly 2003, didnot materialize. As a result, public finances were less than expected, despite the fact that revenue collections were on target. Domestic net credit to the government increased to finance the additional expenditures and shortfalls in donor grants, leading to an overall deficit (excluding grants) o f 10.5% o f GDP in2003.
7. The above factors exacerbate the vulnerability o f the extemal accounts to extemal shocks, and this vulnerability i s compounded by the heavy reliance on a few commodities for exports. At present, the current account deficit is estimated to be around 19.8 percent o f GDP (compared to the programmed level for 2003 o f 18.7 percent, and which is programmed to increase to roughly 21 percent in2004). Rwanda continues to rely heavily on coffee and tea, which consist o f about 60 percent o f total exports. Coffee production and exports fell in2003 due to a combination o f low international coffee prices, drought conditions, and older plants. Tea production, which accounts for the largest foreign exchange eamings (estimated at US$22 million), declined slightly in 2003 due to the drought. These events led to a US$4 million drop inmerchandise exports, which resulted inUS$63 millionofexports, in2003.
8. The above events, coupled with construction related bank lending, led to a faster than programmed expansion in the monetary aggregates and rapid exchange rate depreciation. Through end-September 2003, some targets under the Intemational Monetary Fund (IMF) PRGF-supported program were not observed. The Government has been aware o f these difficulties, and has reached an agreement on revised targets and has asked for waivers in order to continue with the program. Presently, the GoR is working with the Bank, (in the context o f the upcoming PRSC), to ensure deepening o f and continued progress in structural reforms to support sustained economic growth, revenue generation and debt sustainability. The GoR does not expect any further deterioration in fiscal and monetary aggregates, (provided donor money comes as programmed in the budget). In order to manage the risk to the budget associated with uncertainty in donor disbursement, the government has identified and agreed on contingent levels o f spending, under the PRGF program, and will continue to seek increased grant financing.
9. The Rwandan private sector is small and weak, as years o f conflict and socio- political mismanagement have driven away private investments. The financial sector is small, burdened with non-performing loans and lacks opportunities for good loans and other investments. Reforms have been initiated to strengthen the financial sector. It was  in that context that the Competitiveness and Enterprise Development Project, aimed at establishing an enabling environment for growth and development o f the private sector in Rwanda, was developed and included a component dedicated to increase financial access through a quasi equity and loan venture capital fund to strengthen the middle and small enterprises in Rwanda.
111. Start Up Fund
10. The Government of Rwanda, has developed an innovative strategy to provide risk capital financing, complemented by intensive business assistance, to a significant number o f Rwanda's most promising small and medium enterprises. Operations are expected to begin in September 2004. The design o f the Rwandan Enterprise Investment Company (the "REIC") has three principal parts:
11. Leveraged capitalization strategy. In order to attract equity Investors into the Rwandan Enterprise Investment Company (REIC) , the Rwandan Ministry o f Finance and Economic Planning (Minecofin) is offering to provide the REIC with a 10-year loan of the Rwanda franc equivalent o f U S D 4 million, at 2% interest (in Rwandan francs), with a five-year grace period on principal payments. The purpose of the Minecofin Loan is first to increase the amount o f money available for the REIC to invest and second, given the potential leveraging effect o f the Minecofin Loan, to provide a strong incentive to the Investors and to the REIC's management team to operate the REIC on a profitable basis by investing inhigh-performance SMEs.
12. It is important to note that the REIC will operate as a private Rwandan entity, owned entirely by its equity Investors, and that the managers o f the REIC will be selected and engaged by the Investors. Investment decisions will be made exclusively by representatives of the Investors. The GoR wishes only to retain the rights o f a lender to receive timely payments of interest and principal and to ensure compliance with the agreed investment policy of the REIC. While this investment policy has been defined in detail by the designers o f the REIC, in essence, it simply calls for the REIC to invest in SMEs of those size and sector characteristics which will provide maximum benefits to the growthand diversification o f the Rwandanprivate sector.
13. Innovative investment strategy. Inaddition to the investment policy imposed on the REIC by the terms o f the Minecofin Loan, the REIC will also be required to operate according to a prescribed investment methodology. This particular methodology has been determined through global research into best practices in S M E risk capital finance. It is designed to take greater risk than would a commercial bank, while taking less risk than would a conventional venture capital fund. Its objective is to provide commercial financing to SMEs which, o n the one hand, cannot offer sufficient collateral to obtain adequate bank financing and, on the other hand, cannot provide realistic prospects for "venture capital" type exits from equity through third-party sales o f shares.  14. More specifically, the investment strategy o f the REIC calls for the combining of a relatively small investment in the equity o f the Investee with a substantially larger shareholder loan. This shareholder loan will carry a low interest rate with additional rights to a small percentage of the gross sales o f the Investee. The benefit o f this "royalty"-based strategy i s to provide growth-orientedfinancing at a cost which i s tied to the performance ofthe Investee. The purpose of limitingthe REIC's exposure inequity in each investment is to allow for repurchase o f the REIC's shares in the Investee at a price which i s realistically affordable to the Investee at the agreed time o f exit. It i s important to recognize that while this quasi-equity strategy clearly constitutes risk capital finance, it i s designed more to avoid the conventional practices o f venture capital than to imitate them
15. Dedicated technical assistance facility. Inan effort to ensurethat each Investee reaches its full economic potential, a grant-based pool o f funds outside the accounts o f the REIC is beingraised to provide for additionaltechnical andbusiness assistance. This T A Facility will be usedto fund third-party assistance andconsultancies on a demand- drivenbasis. Thenature o feachinterventionwill be defined collaborativelybythe Investees and the managers o f the REIC. Examples o fthe TA Facility's use include assistance inaccounting and informationsystems, development o f marketingstrategies and materials, sourcing o f appropriate technology andraw materials, and training o f management and workers.
IV. Conditions for Tranche Release
16. As stated in Part A.6 of Schedule 1of the DCA, the release of S M E tranche is subject to the following conditions:
(a) the macro-economic policy framework o f the Borrower is satisfactory, as measured on the basis o f indicators agreed between the Borrower and the Association;
(b) the Borrower has achieved progress satisfactory to the Association incarrying out the Program;
(c) that with respect to Categories 3(b)(i) and 3(b)(ii), the Borrower has provided evidence satisfactory in form and in substance to the Association that the start up fund (Rwanda Small Loan Fund and Rwanda Risk Capital Fund) for SMEs has been established underterms and conditions satisfactory to the Association.
V. Meeting Conditions for Tranche Release
17. 'The macro-economic policy framework of the Borrower. As measured using indicators agreed between the Borrower and the Association, i s satisfactory to IDA. The finding o f compliance is based on IDA review o f the agreed upon indicators o f performance, as reflected in the recent Joint Staff Assessment o f the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper approved by the Bank's Board on June 8, 2004. Such findings were  confirmed by IMF staff review o f the macroeconomic situation in mid-2004 carried out in July 2004 and the IMF Board approval on July 24, 2004 o f a 3-year PRGF arrangement.
18. Program Implementation. Overall, the project implementation is rated highly satisfactory and all the project activities are being carried out in accordance with the agreed work plan matrix. The disbursement to date i s SDR 11.1 million (US$15.5 million) representing 35% of the credit proceed. It is most likely that end o f year target o f US$9.4 million could be reached with the release o f SME tranche. The project continues to perform satisfactorily and i s in compliance with the Bank's procurement and financial procedures while meeting its coordination challenges o f the project activities implemented by twelve various agencies. Regular quarterly project implementation reports, including an update on the project annual work plan, are sent to the Bank.
19. After 3.5 years o f project implementation, the Borrower has achieved progress satisfactory to IDAinimplementing the program, evident by the following actions:
(i) undertheprivatizationcomponent: ELECTROGAZ has been under management contract since October 2003. The Private Operator i s performing satisfactorily despite the current energy crisis inRwanda; 0 RWANDATELwas offered for sale since April 26, 2004. Several bidders have purchased the bidding documents and have also conducted due diligence o f the company. The bid proposal will be submitted on October 25,2004; 0 BCR (commercial bank o f Rwanda) has been offered for sale and a preferred investor has been selected. The Transaction was completed in September 2004; and 0 The privatization o f the two pilot tea factories and estates has been completed. The preferred bidder for the Pfunda Tea factory and the govemment finalized the sale on September 24,2004. The handingover o f the tea factory will take place inNovember 2004. The second tea factory, Mulindi, will be offered for sale again as the offered prices were too low and Government had to reject the bids after all efforts to increase the sale price upwards failed.
(ii) underthe Business and legal environment improvement component:
0 The Arbitration Center has been established and training for its additional staff has been completed. The framework for establishment o f the Commercial Chambers i s ongoing meanwhile the judges have been appointed;
0 The Financial Sector studies haves been completed, including the financial sector assessment study whose recommendations are currently being implemented;  The newly-established RPA (Rwanda Investment Promotion Agency) is operational and its one-shop window for investors commenced operations inApril 2004. It takes 21 days to complete all necessary paper work for investors to cornmence operation in Rwanda. Annual Investment Conferences have been successfully held inKigali with over 200 foreign investors participating from 27 countries including Asia, Australia, Europe, Canada and USA;
The applicable pre-conditions, for the release o f the Start Up Funds have beenmet and there are two other investors who have pledged to invest in the fund and;
(iii) Underthe private sector development component:
0 The business plan competition (BPC) was launched inMay and over 400 business plans were submitted by August 15, 2004. The winners will be announced by December 2004 and they can acquire the skills they need to execute their business plans, gain access to finance, and build a credit history and;
The design of REIC was approved by the Government. The REIC has three principal parts: (i)a leveraged capitalization strategy; (ii)an innovative investment strategy; and (iii)a dedicated technical assistance facility.
VI. Conclusion
20. Inview of the overall performance and progress with the implementation of the program supported by the Credit, and in compliance with the specific conditions o f release as described inparagraph 6 o f Schedule 1 to the Development Credit Agreement, the Association has informed the Borrower of the availability of the SME tranche for Rwanda Small Loan Fund and Rwanda Risk Capital Fund in the amount of SDR 3,890,000 to strengthen growth inthe SME sector o fRwanda.

doc.repnme: Rwanda : Competitiveness and Enterprise Development Project - Release of second tranche : full compliance
doc.abstracts: The objective of the Competitiveness and Enterprise Development Project is to establish an enabling environment for private sector-led economic growth and poverty reduction within Rwanda. Recent economic developments include the election of a new government; satisfactory performance under the first annual Poverty Reduction Growth Facility (PRGF) review; exacerbation of the country's fiscal situation and external account vulnerability; and expansion in the monetary aggregates and rapid exchange rate depreciation. The conditions for the release of SME tranche have been met by: satisfactory macro-economic policy framework of the Borrower; highly satisfactory project implementation ratings; and progress under the privatization component, business and legal environment improvement component, and private sector development component. IDA has informed the Borrower of the availability of the SME tranche in the amount of SDR 3,890,000 to strengthen growth in the SME sector of Rwanda.
